title: CA divorce law, criminal liability for forged signature on pleading
question: My husband filed dissolution case without my acknowledgement. He forged my signature and proof of wummons. I've received Notice of Entry of Judgement by mail from husband. I want to divorce, but it is not
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal charges,Criminal charges for forgery,Lawsuits and disputes
answers: While you're correct that it wasn't the 'right way' to do it, the question you must ask yourself is whether your husband gained an unfair advantage in the Judgment by it terms, For example, did the two of you have any property that needs to be divided equally, or did you have any debts that also would need to be shared between you. I am assuming that you don't have any minor children (as they aren't mentioned) but if you've been married awhile, then you may be entitled to support, or even if it's a short-term marriage, and you are earning significantly less money than him. The bottom line is that if you think the terms of the Judgment are unfair, then you should contact an attorney to file papers to get the court to 'undo' and then 'redo' the Judgment after a trial; if not, then maybe in the long term, it is the easier way. Either way, a consultation with an attorney would hopefully clarify your options.

If you want to set it aside you should contact the district attorney and bring it to their attention if you wish to file criminal charges. Further, you should file a Notice of Motion to set aside the Judgment as soon as possible. Also the Judgement which was entered may deny you important property or support rights. if thta is the case you may also claim that he breached some important fiduciary duties and that you should be awarded that property. Consult an attorney.

Forgery is a crime, there is no doubt about that. The problem is that you want the divorce, you got the divorce, but you did not sign any papers.

If you want to bring this to the attention to the Court, you are going to have to file a motion to set aside the default. You need to do it within 6 months of the notice of entry of judgement otherwise it may be difficult to get it set aside.

You should retain an attorney to handle this matter for you. You may call me for a free consultation at 818-584-8831 ext.1
